Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
@jl777 I'm working through Komodo API documentation, looking to clean up, remove some references to Zcash, and provide more info.

While starting `komodod`, I noticed this announcement:

```
Warning: This version will be deprecated at block height 1009664, and will automatically shut down. You should upgrade to the latest version of Zcash. To disable deprecation for this version, set -disabledeprecation=1.0.15.
```

How difficult is it to change Zcash to Komodo, within the code? Would it break things?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i already fixed that in my working branch

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: okay, great

Author: ttt#3928
Content:
Hello, could someone explain me why komodo try such kind of connection and it fail all time? Maybe it possible to disable it?2018-09-05 07:20:45 connect() to 52.65.58.103:26061 failed after select(): Connection refused (111)
2018-09-05 07:20:47 connect() to 217.182.203.106:26061 failed after select(): Connection refused (111)
2018-09-05 07:21:03 connect() to 95.213.238.98:26061 failed after select(): Connection refused (111)
2018-09-05 07:21:10 connect() to 78.47.196.146:26061 failed after select(): Connection refused (111)
2018-09-05 07:21:17 connect() to 178.128.25.203:26061 failed after select(): Connection refused (111)
2018-09-05 07:21:26 connect() to 159.65.134.48:26061 failed after select(): Connection refused (111)

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: The other side is refusing.  Maybe there is no daemon running on their end, maybe they have too many connections to other daemons and they are not accepting your connection.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: there's other reasons as well, but they are the simple ones.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all peers are tried, not all succeed. this is normal and part of being a p2p network

Author: ttt#3928
Content: Another one qestion about mining, after starting ./komodod on my server with static IP and connecting a few clients, i mined only 128 blocks on one chain, to mine  additional blocks it's need to create additional chain? or there is some other ways?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you dont specify -ac_reward, then it defaults to an on-demand chain.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in that case, new blocks only where there are new transactions

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
Looking at this first command, I'm wondering if there's a reason why we have it in our documentation the way we do, or if this is something I can change.

Right now, we have this:

```
Arguments:

{
  "addresses"
    [
      "address"  (string) The base58check encoded address
      ,...
    ]
}
```

I'm wondering if we can put a `:` after `"addresses"`, or is there a documentation formality that we're following by not putting it there?

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
Also, does anyone have any tips about how to set it in the terminal so that the first part of the command I'm writing I don't have to retype all the time?

So, rather than typing `./komodo-cli` in front of every command, just have something where, at least temporarily, I can go straight to `getbalance ...`

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: same for assets, like `./komodo-cli -ac_name=DEX -ac_supply=999999`

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: want to just put that as a default on the terminal, for at least the current session.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Another question..., what command would you use on this list to just display the list of addresses in the wallet, along with the current amount in each address? If there is such a command.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: create a script

Author: Alright#0419
Content:
```
#!/bin/bash
./komodo-cli -ac_name=<CHAINNAME> $1
```

Author: Alright#0419
Content: save that as a file then do `chmod -x <filename>`

Author: Alright#0419
Content: then you can do `./<filename> <command>`

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: hmm, okay.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I've played around with that once on something else, will try it again here. Thank you.

Content: Is there a reason why we shouldn't be a `:` after `"addresses"`?

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
Right now we have this:
```
Arguments:

{
  "addresses"
    [
      "address"  (string) The base58check encoded address
      ,...
    ]
}
```
and I'm wondering if we can change it to the following, or if there's a reason why we don't have the `:` in the argument
```
Arguments:

{
  "addresses":
    [
      "address"  (string) The base58check encoded address
      ,...
    ]
}
```

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I wondered if it might have something to do with the way C++ or Linux terminal documentation is usually written, or if it's changeable.
